Consider the paraconsistent logic statement below:

((p ∧ ¬q) ⊕ (¬p ∧ q)) → (p ⊕ q)

Given that p and q are either true (T) or false (F), determine the truth value of the statement.
message_2:
To determine the truth value of the statement, we need to consider all possible combinations of truth values for p and q, and then evaluate the statement for each combination.

1. p = T, q = T:
((T ∧ ¬T) ⊕ (¬T ∧ T)) → (T ⊕ T)
((F) ⊕ (F)) → (F)
(F) → (F)
This is true, as in paraconsistent logic, a false statement implies a false statement.

2. p = T, q = F:
((T ∧ ¬F) ⊕ (¬T ∧ F)) → (T ⊕ F)
((T) ⊕ (F)) → (T)
(T) → (T)
This is true, as in classical and paraconsistent logic, a true statement implies a true statement.

3. p = F, q = T:
((F ∧ ¬T) ⊕ (¬F ∧ T)) → (F ⊕ T)
((F) ⊕ (T)) → (T)
(T) → (T)
This is true, as in classical and paraconsistent logic, a true statement implies a true statement.

4. p = F, q = F:
((F ∧ ¬F) ⊕ (¬F ∧ F)) → (F ⊕ F)
((F) ⊕ (F)) → (F)
(F) → (F)
This is true, as in paraconsistent logic, a false statement implies a false statement.

In all possible combinations of truth values for p and q, the statement is true. Therefore, the truth value of the statement is true.
